unnormalised: As someone who's navigated the Indian education system, I can definitely shed some light on how academic results and grading generally work here. It's a bit more nuanced than just a simple percentage.
normalised: As someone who has navigated the Indian education system, I can definitely shed some light on how academic results and grading generally work here. It's a bit more nuanced than just a simple percentage.

unnormalised: First off, you'll encounter various grading systems. The most common one is the percentage system, where your marks are directly expressed as a percentage, e.g., 85%, 60%, 92%. Scoring 90%+ often puts you in the "distinction" category. Scoring above 60 % is considered first class.
normalised: First off, you will encounter various grading systems. The most common one is the percentage system, where your marks are directly expressed as a percentage, e.g., eighty five percent, sixty percent, ninety two percent. Scoring ninety percent plus often puts you in the "distinction" category. Scoring above sixty percent is considered first class.

unnormalised: But the Central Board of Secondary Education, or CBSE, which a lot of schools follow, also uses a grading system with letter grades. These range from A1 (highest) to E (failing). An A1 usually corresponds to the top 1/8th of students, scoring somewhere around 91% to 100% or so, depending on the subject and difficulty. An A2 might be 81%-90%. B1 71-80%.
normalised: But the Central Board of Secondary Education, or C-B-S-E, which a lot of schools follow, also uses a grading system with letter grades. These range from A one (highest) to E (failing). An A one usually corresponds to the top one eighth of students, scoring somewhere around ninety one percent to one hundred percent or so, depending on the subject and difficulty. An A two might be eighty one percent to ninety percent. B one seventy one to eighty percent.

unnormalised: State boards also exist, and they often have their own unique grading schemes. For example, some state boards might use a system with just numbers (1-7 or 1-9), where 1 is the highest and 7 or 9 is failing. Your GPA could differ greatly from state to state, and within institutions themselves. If you are planning to pursue higher education from a place other than where you completed your secondary school, this is something that you should take into consideration.

unnormalised: Beyond the grades themselves, relative performance matters a lot, especially in competitive exams like JEE (Joint Entrance Examination) or NEET (National Eligibility cum Entrance Test). In JEE, a score of 200/300 might get you a good rank, depending on the difficulty level of that year's paper, especially if your competition is equally as prepared. Similarly, in NEET, a score of 650/720 is generally considered a very good score that will get you into a decent government medical college. These are highly dependent on difficulty, and will shift year to year.
normalised: Beyond the grades themselves, relative performance matters a lot, especially in competitive exams like J-E-E (Joint Entrance Examination) or N-E-E-T (National Eligibility cum Entrance Test). In J-E-E, a score of two hundred divided by three hundred might get you a good rank, depending on the difficulty level of that year's paper, especially if your competition is equally as prepared. Similarly, in N-E-E-T, a score of six hundred and fifty divided by seven hundred and twenty is generally considered a very good score that will get you into a decent government medical college. These are highly dependent on difficulty, and will shift year to year.

unnormalised: Also, grace marks are sometimes awarded, particularly in subjects where a large number of students have struggled. This could be, say, 5 marks given to everyone who scored below passing in a particularly difficult Math exam, thereby increasing the overall pass percentage. Keep in mind, academic culture in India can be fairly challenging and competitive. With millions of students competing for a limited number of seats in prestigious colleges and universities, the pressure to perform well is intense.

unnormalised: Colleges often set their cut-off percentages extremely high, sometimes reaching 95% or even 99% for popular courses. This means that students need to score exceptionally well to secure a place in their desired program. Some colleges may also consider entrance exams or interviews in addition to academic grades. So, while scoring high in your exams is important, it's also crucial to prepare well for any additional admission requirements.
